i Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â July Â â€“ Â September Â 2015 Â
1 . Â O P E R A T I O N A L Â A C T I V I T I E S Â A N D Â T E C H N I C A L Â A S S I S T A N C E Â Â
1.1 Â R EGIONAL Â A CTIVITIES Â Â A F R I C A N Â U N I O N Â D D R Â C A P A C I T Y Â P R O G R A M Â ( A U Â D D R C P ) Â Â Â Â Â Â Â M e t h o d o l o g y Â W o r k s h o p Â o n Â t h e Â c o l l a b o r a t i v e Â A s s e s s m e n t Â o f Â N o n Â S t a t e Â A r m e d Â G r o u p s Â Â From Â 13-Â­â€14 Â July Â 2015, Â the Â African Â Union Â Commission Â (AUC) Â convened Â a Â methodology Â workshop Â on Â the Â collaborative Â assessment Â of Â non-Â­â€state Â armed Â groups Â in Â Addis Â Ababa, Â Ethiopia. Â The Â meeting Â was Â organized Â as Â a Â follow-Â­â€up Â from Â the Â main Â outcomes Â agreed Â upon Â from Â the Â 4th Â African Â Union Â Small Â Arms Â Light Â Weapons/Disarmament Â Demobilization Â and Â Reintegration Â (DDR) Â Steering Â Committee Â Meeting Â held Â in Â Lusaka, Â Zambia Â from Â 8-Â­â€9 Â December Â 2014, Â where Â a Â concept Â paper Â on Â â€œAssessment Â of Â Non-Â­â€ Â Non Â State Â Armed Â Groups Â (NSAGs) Â and Â Advancing Â Stabilization, Â DDR, Â and Â Cross Â Border Â Security Â and Â Development Â Efforts Â on Â the Â African Â Continentâ€ Â was Â presented, Â and Â discussed. Â Â The Â workshops Â helped Â the Â AUC Â and Â its Â partners Â to Â shape Â the Â analytical Â guidelines, Â provided Â conceptual Â clarity Â and Â outlined Â the Â approach Â and Â methodology Â in Â the Â concept Â note Â for Â the Â study. Â Â A Â detailed Â Operational Â plan Â of Â the Â study Â was Â also Â presented, Â and Â the Â Terms Â of Â Reference Â (ToRs) Â of Â the Â SALWs/DDR Â Steering Â Committee Â (SCM) Â Task Â Team/Sub-Â­â€Committee Â serving Â as Â a Â Critical Â Review Â Panel Â for Â the Â execution Â of Â the Â study Â was Â discussed Â as Â well. Â Â Â These Â intended Â outcomes Â will Â support Â the Â final Â review Â and Â adjustment Â of Â the Â scope Â of Â the Â study Â accordingly, Â and Â will Â also Â help Â to Â enhance Â a Â collaborative Â and Â coherent Â engagement Â strategy Â by Â all Â partners Â interested Â in Â the Â study Â and Â its Â future Â outcomes. Â Â D S D Â F o l l o w -Â­â€ Â u p Â A s s e s s m e n t Â M i s s i o n Â t o Â M o g a d i s h u , Â S o m a l i a Â Â From Â September Â 16-Â­â€17, Â 2015, Â as Â part Â of Â the Â AU Â Disarmament, Â Demobilization Â and Â Reintegration Â (DDR) Â Capacity Â program, Â the Â Defense Â and Â Security Â Division Â (DSD) Â undertook Â an Â assessment Â mission Â on Â Disarmament, Â Demobilization Â and Â Reintegration Â (DDR), Â including Â on Â the Â Reception Â and Â Hand-Â­â€Over Â of Â Children Â Separated Â from Â Armed Â Groups Â in Â Somalia. Â The Â assessment Â mission Â included Â four Â critical Â aspects Â of Â security, Â stabilization Â and Â development, Â namely Â (i) Â Disarmament, Â Demobilization Â and Â Reintegration Â (DDR) Â including Â arms Â management, Â (ii) Â Security Â Sector Â Reform Â (SSR), Â (iii) Â the Â reception Â and Â hand-Â­â€over Â of Â children Â and Â (iv) Â women Â separated Â from Â armed Â groups. Â Â Â DSD Â undertook Â the Â mission Â to Â provide Â vital Â DDR Â support Â to Â AMISOM, Â as Â part Â of Â their Â mandate Â to Â assist Â in Â the Â implementation Â of Â the Â National Â Security Â Stabilization Â Program Â (NSSP). Â The Â mission Â met Â with Â AMISOM, Â particularly Â with Â DDR/Disengaging Â combatants, Â Security Â Sector Â Reform Â and Â Gender Â peace Â and Â Security Â officers, Â United Â Nations Â Support Â to Â Somalia Â (UNSOM) Â and Â the Â Federal Â Government Â of Â Somalia Â (FGS). Â Â Â
1 Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â July Â â€“ Â September Â 2015 Â
The Â team Â concluded Â its Â consultation Â and Â outlined Â specific Â follow-Â­â€up Â recommendation Â through Â the Â development Â of Â an Â implementation Â matrix Â which Â identifies Â key Â activities Â as Â well Â as Â the Â lead Â person. Â In Â addition, Â the Â team Â also Â stressed Â need Â for Â follow Â up Â and Â expedite Â the Â recruitment Â process Â of Â the Â DDR Â and Â SSR Â consultants Â to Â be Â deployed Â to Â AMISOM. Â Lastly, Â the Â mission Â team Â also Â discussed Â and Â considered Â the Â training Â of Â the Â disengaging Â combatants Â SOP Â and Â the Â AU Â DDR Â guidance Â documents Â as Â part Â of Â pre-Â­â€ deployment Â training. Â Â O p e r a t i o n s Â G u i d a n c e Â N o t e s Â o n Â F o r e i g n Â F i g h t e r s Â ( F F ) Â a n d Â C o u n t e r i n g Â V i o l e n t Â E x t r e m i s m Â ( C V E ) Â Â TDRP Â hired Â consultants Â to Â assist Â in Â the Â development Â of Â Operations Â Guidance Â Notes Â on Â FF Â and Â CVE. Â The Â outlines Â of Â the Â documents Â are Â currently Â developed Â and Â undergoing Â a Â review Â process. Â Â Â Â F o u r t h Â A U Â D D R Â N e w s l e t t e r Â P u b l i s h e d Â Â The Â fourth Â AU Â DDR Â Newsletter Â issue Â was Â published Â in Â August Â 2015. Â The Â newly Â released Â newsletter Â highlighted Â the Â launch Â of Â the Â AU Â DDR Â site, Â and Â provided Â brief Â summary Â of Â important Â meetings Â and Â workshops Â that Â took Â place Â during Â the Â last Â phase. Â Besides Â the Â workshop Â on Â the Â Development Â of Â an Â AU Â DDR Â Compendium Â and Â Training Â Standards Â Manual Â in Â Addis Â Ababa, Â there Â were Â also Â the Â Fifth Â Meeting Â of Â the Â AU Â -Â­â€ Â Regions Â Steering Â Committee Â on Â SALW/DDR, Â Methodology Â Workshop Â on Â the Â collaborative Â Assessment Â of Â Non Â State Â Armed Â Groups Â and Â Senior Â Government Â Officials Â Meeting Â on Â the Â Arms Â Trade Â Treaty. Â In Â addition, Â a Â Child Â Protection Â Study Â Tour Â for Â Somali Â Officials Â happened Â in Â Uganda, Â and Â AU Â sends Â RECs/RM Â Representatives Â to Â an Â advanced Â stabilization Â and Â reintegration Â DDR Â training. Â Â
1.2 Â C OUNTRY Â A CTIVITIES Â Â C E N T R A L Â A F R I C A N Â R E P U B L I C Â Â In Â this Â quarter, Â TDRP Â continued Â working Â with Â the Â United Â Nations Â Multidimensional Â Integrated Â Stabilization Â Mission Â in Â the Â Central Â African Â Republic Â (MINUSCA) Â DDR Â team Â in Â the Â development Â of Â national Â DDR Â program. Â A Â TDRP Â mission Â visited Â Bangui Â in Â September Â 2015 Â and Â met Â with Â officials Â from Â the Â Transitional Â Government Â who Â are Â working Â on Â DDR Â and Â Security Â Sector Â Reform, Â World Â Bank Â country Â team Â and Â MINUSCA Â leadership. Â In Â this Â quarter, Â TDPR Â and Â MINUSCA Â DDR Â developed Â a Â joint Â proposal Â for Â financing Â support Â from Â the Â UN-Â­â€World Â Bank Â Partnership Â Trust Â Fund, Â which Â aims Â to Â deepen Â cooperation Â between Â the Â World Â Bank Â and Â the Â UN Â in Â fragile Â and Â conflict-Â­â€affected Â situations. Â TDRP Â and Â MINUSCA Â DDR Â teams Â will Â develop Â terms Â of Â reference Â for Â socio-Â­â€economic Â assessment Â of Â beneficiaries Â and Â communities Â and Â mapping Â of Â potential Â implementing Â partners. Â TDRP Â will Â continue Â supporting Â MINUSCA Â and Â the Â Government Â through Â continued Â coordination Â and Â technical Â assistance Â during Â the Â pre-Â­â€DDR Â process. Â Â D E M O C R A T I C Â R E P U B L I C Â O F Â C O N G O Â Â D D R Â I I I Â
2 Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â July Â â€“ Â September Â 2015 Â
On Â July Â 09th Â 2015, Â another Â major Â step Â was Â accomplished Â with Â the Â signing Â of Â the Â legal Â documents Â (Financial Â Agreement Â & Â Grant Â Agreement) Â of Â the Â Reinsertion Â & Â Reintegration Â Project, Â in Â Kinshasa, Â by Â the Â Minister Â of Â Finance Â and Â the Â World Â Bank Â Country Â Director. Â Following Â the Â signatures Â of Â the Â legal Â accords, Â a Â World Â Bank/TDRP Â mission Â travelled Â to Â Kinshasa Â from Â July Â 20 Â -Â­â€ Â 30 Â with Â the Â objectives Â to Â start Â the Â preparation Â of Â the Â ESMF Â (Environmental Â Social Â and Â Management Â Framework), Â the Â baseline Â and Â to Â closely Â follow-Â­â€up Â on Â the Â status Â of Â the Â project Â effectiveness. Â During Â the Â mission Â the Â Sr. Â Social Â Safeguard Â Specialist Â worked Â with Â the Â UEPNDDR Â to Â prepare Â the Â required Â ToRs Â for Â the Â ESMF Â and Â also Â conducted Â a Â training Â on Â the Â grievance Â redress Â mechanism Â that Â need Â to Â be Â put Â in Â place. Â The Â mission, Â which Â included Â the Â WB Â Sr. Â Financial Â Management Â Expert Â and Â Procurement Â Specialist, Â held Â many Â working Â sessions Â with Â the Â UEPNDDR Â to Â advance Â the Â preparation Â of Â the Â Project Â Implementation Â Manual. Â In Â addition, Â the Â mission Â received Â updates Â from Â the Â UEPNDDR Â on Â the Â preliminary Â activities Â of Â the Â Project Â related Â to Â disarmament Â and Â demobilization Â and Â a Â total Â of Â 4,189 Â person Â (including Â 89 Â female) Â have Â been Â demobilized Â at Â the Â end Â of Â July Â in Â the Â CTA Â in Â Kitona Â and Â Kamina. Â Based Â on Â the Â mission Â recommendation, Â the Â UEPNDDR Â finalized Â a Â new Â version Â of Â the Â PIM, Â and Â a Â last Â set Â of Â comments Â has Â been Â sent Â to Â the Â UEPNDDR Â to Â have Â a Â final Â version Â ready Â by Â early Â October. Â Regarding Â the Â effectiveness, Â the Â GoDRC Â reviewed Â the Â signed Â accords Â during Â a Â commission Â and Â it Â is Â expected Â to Â be Â approved Â during Â a Â Council Â of Â Minister Â in Â early Â October Â to Â finally Â receive Â the Â legal Â opinion Â â€“ Â the Â Project Â should Â therefore Â be Â effective Â before Â the Â end Â of Â October. Â In Â addition, Â the Â WB/TDRP Â continued Â to Â follow Â up Â with Â interested Â donors Â to Â contribute Â to Â the Â established Â MDTF, Â and Â a Â new Â contribution Â from Â the Â EU Â is Â expected Â for Â the Â month Â of Â October. Â Finally, Â a Â WB/TDRP Â mission Â went Â to Â Kinshasa Â at Â the Â end Â of Â September/ Â early Â October Â to Â continue Â to Â follow-Â­â€up Â and Â to Â ensure Â that Â activities Â will Â start Â as Â soon Â as Â possible Â â€“ Â this Â mission Â will Â be Â reported Â in Â the Â next Â Quarterly Â Report. Â
J a p a n Â S o c i a l Â D e v e l o p m e n t Â F u n d Â ( J S D F ) : Â S o c i a l Â C o h e s i o n Â a n d Â L i v e l i h o o d Â S u p p o r t Â P r o j e c t Â i n Â P r o v i n c e Â O r i e n t a l e Â Â The Â team Â received Â comments Â from Â the Â JSDF Â on Â the Â DRC Â project Â concept Â note Â package Â and Â submitted Â the Â revised Â package Â including Â cost Â table Â in Â September. Â The Â team Â is Â awaiting Â clearance Â on Â the Â concept Â package Â from Â Japan Â to Â proceed Â to Â the Â next Â step Â of Â project Â appraisal Â package Â preparation. Â It Â is Â planned Â to Â submit Â the Â package Â before Â the Â end Â of Â this Â calendar Â year Â to Â launch Â the Â project Â in Â the Â first Â quarter Â of Â 2016. Â Â M A L I Â Â In Â August, Â the Â World Â Bank Â Country Â Management Â Unit Â requested Â the Â TDRP Â team Â to Â develop Â the Â concept Â for Â a Â reinsertion Â project. Â As Â an Â integral Â part Â of Â the Â global Â DDR Â program, Â the Â project Â would Â provide Â reinsertion Â support Â to Â disarmed Â and Â demobilized Â ex-Â­â€combatants Â through Â a Â community-Â­â€based Â approach. Â It Â is Â expected Â that Â the Â new Â project Â will Â be Â co-Â­â€financed Â by Â World Â Bankâ€™s Â International Â Development Â Association Â (IDA) Â and Â a Â new Â multi-Â­â€donor Â trust Â fund Â to Â channel Â donor Â contributions. Â In Â October, Â a Â TDRP Â mission Â will Â travel Â to Â Bamako Â to Â discuss Â the Â reinsertion Â project Â concept Â with Â stakeholders Â including Â the Â Government, Â World Â Bank Â country Â team, Â the Â United Â Nations Â Multidimensional Â Integrated Â Stabilization Â Mission Â in Â Mali Â (MINUSMA) Â DDR Â Unit Â and Â development Â partners. Â To Â inform Â the Â design Â of Â reinsertion Â activities, Â TDRP Â has Â been Â working Â with Â a Â local Â research Â institute Â to Â conduct Â a Â rapid Â survey Â of Â armed Â groups. Â In Â addition, Â TDRP Â technical Â support Â continued Â in Â this Â quarter, Â focusing Â on Â organizational Â set-Â­â€up Â and Â institutional Â framework Â of Â DDR. 3 Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â July Â â€“ Â September Â 2015 Â
Â S o u t h Â S u d a n Â D D R Â T e c h n i c a l Â A s s i s t a n c e Â
This Â quarter Â the Â Republic Â of Â South Â Sudan Â made Â important Â progress Â when Â on Â August Â 27, Â 2015 Â President Â Kiir Â signed Â a Â peace Â agreement Â with Â the Â opposition Â forces, Â officially Â ending Â the Â conflict Â which Â has Â been Â ongoing Â since Â December Â 2013. Â While Â there Â are Â still Â challenges Â in Â terms Â of Â enforcement Â and Â additional Â work Â to Â be Â done Â to Â fill Â out Â the Â implementation Â detail Â for Â the Â agreement, Â the Â signing Â of Â the Â agreement Â is Â a Â crucial Â milestone Â for Â the Â country. Â The Â TDRP Â team Â has Â maintained Â an Â open Â dialogue Â with Â the Â South Â Sudan Â National Â DDR Â Commission Â (NDDRC) Â throughout Â this Â crisis Â particularly Â regarding Â the Â countryâ€™s Â DDR Â strategy Â moving Â forward Â and Â has Â encouraged Â the Â NDDRC Â to Â advise Â the Â peace Â talks Â on Â the Â implementation Â details Â of Â the Â agreement Â so Â as Â to Â avoid Â some Â of Â the Â pitfalls Â which Â followed Â the Â CPA Â agreement. Â Â The Â TDRP Â team Â is Â also Â in Â the Â process Â of Â briefing Â new Â World Â Bank Â country Â team Â management Â on Â these Â issues Â to Â continue Â the Â positive Â momentum Â developed Â over Â the Â course Â of Â the Â DDR Â Pilot Â Reintegration Â Project. Â J a p a n Â S o c i a l Â D e v e l o p m e n t Â F u n d Â ( J S D F ) : Â E c o n o m i c Â E m p o w e r m e n t Â T r a i n i n g Â f o r Â C o n f l i c t -Â­â€ A f f e c t e d Â Y o u t h Â P r o j e c t Â The Â Project Â Concept Â Note Â for Â the Â South Â Sudan Â Economic Â Empowerment Â Training Â for Â Conflict-Â­â€Affected Â Youth Â Project Â is Â currently Â under Â consideration Â by Â the Â Japanese Â representatives Â of Â the Â JSDF Â committee Â following Â approval Â by Â the Â country Â team Â in Â late Â May Â 2015. Â The Â project Â aims Â to Â provide Â an Â economic Â empowerment Â training Â program Â for Â conflict-Â­â€affected Â youth Â in Â South Â Sudan Â through Â development Â of Â the Â curriculum, Â skilling Â of Â trainers Â and Â piloting Â the Â training. Â This Â is Â a Â critical Â initiative Â as Â it Â will Â enhance Â the Â countryâ€™s Â training Â capacity Â which Â will Â be Â necessary Â for Â eventual Â implementation Â of Â any Â DDR Â program Â in Â the Â country. Â At Â the Â same Â time Â there Â is Â widespread Â agreement Â that Â livelihoods Â support Â for Â youth Â is Â a Â priority Â in Â South Â Sudan. Â Â Â R E P U B L I C Â O F Â C O N G O Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â J a p a n Â S o c i a l Â D e v e l o p m e n t Â F u n d Â ( J S D F ) Â The Â team Â also Â received Â comments Â from Â the Â JSDF Â on Â the Â RoC Â project Â concept Â note Â package Â and Â submitted Â the Â revised Â package Â including Â cost Â table Â in Â September. Â The Â team Â is Â awaiting Â clearance Â on Â the Â concept Â package Â from Â Japan Â to Â proceed Â to Â the Â next Â step Â of Â project Â appraisal Â package Â preparation. Â It Â is Â planned Â to Â submit Â the Â package Â before Â the Â end Â of Â this Â calendar Â year Â to Â launch Â the Â project Â in Â the Â first Â quarter Â of Â 2016. Â
2 . Â K N O W L E D G E Â M A N A G E M E N T Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â
2.1 Â C ONFERENCES Â AND Â W ORKSHOPS Â Â Â A Â key Â component Â of Â TDRPâ€™s Â knowledge Â management Â is Â disseminating Â knowledge Â on Â conflict Â and Â post-Â­â€ conflict Â issues Â through Â workshops Â and Â conferences. Â Â W O R K S H O P Â I N Â T H E Â P H I L I P P I N E S Â Â Â Â Â Â
4 Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â July Â â€“ Â September Â 2015 Â
Â The Â TDRP Â was Â requested Â to Â share Â best Â practice Â from Â its Â projects Â with Â the Â Bangsamoro Â Normalization Â (Reintegration) Â Program Â in Â the Â Philippines Â and Â the Â ACR Â (the Â Colombian Â Agency Â for Â Reintegration). Â Presentations Â to Â the Â Government Â of Â Philippines, Â the Â Bangsamoro Â Normalization Â Commission, Â and Â the Â Joint Â Normalization Â Committee Â were Â centered Â on Â how Â the Â TDRP Â has Â structured Â Trust Â Funds Â and Â Implementation Â modalities Â in Â projects Â in Â Africa. Â To Â the Â same Â bodies, Â as Â well Â as Â to Â the Â ACR, Â colleagues Â in Â these Â DDR Â programs Â were Â interested Â in Â Institutional Â arrangements Â as Â well Â as Â reintegration Â modalities. Â The Â TDRP Â has Â also Â worked Â to Â produce Â a Â draft Â paper Â on Â Violence Â Extremism Â and Â Radicalization, Â which Â looks Â at Â strategies Â employed Â to Â counter Â both Â trends Â and Â how Â these Â can Â possibly Â be Â used Â in Â DDR Â programing. Â Â
3 . Â P R O G R A M Â M A N A G E M E N T Â Â Â Â Â TFC Â M EETING Â Â Â The Â objectives Â of Â the Â upcoming Â TDRP Â TFC Â meeting Â in Â October Â 19-Â­â€10 Â are Â (i) Â to Â provide Â an Â update Â on Â TDRP Â implementation; Â (ii) Â to Â present Â the Â findings Â of Â the Â external Â TDRP Â evaluation; Â and Â (iii) Â to Â present Â and Â discuss Â the Â strategic Â vision Â and Â program Â concept. Â To Â this Â end, Â during Â the Â past Â quarter, Â the Â external Â evaluators Â had Â interviews Â and Â discussions Â with Â the Â development Â partners, Â African Â Union, Â United Â Nations, Â DDR Â Commissions Â and Â World Â Bank Â colleagues. Â The Â Manager Â for Â the Â Social Â Urban Â and Â Rural Â Resilience Â Global Â Practice Â will Â also Â participate Â in Â the Â upcoming Â meeting. Â Â

doc.repnme: Transitional Demobilization and Reintegration Program (TDRP) quarterly report : July - September 2015
doc.abstracts: This quarterly report covers the months of July, August, and September 2015. Over this period, the Transitional Demobilization and Reintegration Program (TDRP) team focused on regional activities, namely quality enhancement and cross border issues.
